label: REFUTES
claim: "Democrat Senators high-five after voting in favor of late-term abortion."
evidences: The senators ' conversation is inaudible .

The video shows Heitkamp walking into the chamber , responding to the clerk ' s roll call in the negative , and chatting with Sen. Cory Booker , D-N.J. Schumer approaches them ; he and Heitkamp wave hello and clasp each other ' s hand .
Aides for Heitkamp and Schumer told PolitiFact in 2018 that the senators were greeting each other and that they did not speak about the vote in their interaction .
Senators voted 51-46 yea-to-nay ; Heitkamp was one of the nay votes .
" Democrat Senators high-five after voting in favor of late-term abortion , " said the headline of a Jan. 30 , 2018 LifeSiteNews.com post that ' s been shared on Facebook .
When Heitkamp and Schumer met , the vote was about halfway through , so the hand clasp was not in reaction to a final tally and their exchange did not look like a high-five .
We fact-checked this claim two years ago when a North Dakota political blog similarly claimed that the two senators high-fived after the controversial abortion vote .
A video clip shows Senators Heitkamp and Schumer engaging in a friendly interaction on the Senate floor, with no indication of discussing the specific vote on late-term abortion.
The senators can be seen greeting each other with a handshake and engaging in a brief conversation, which is a common occurrence among colleagues in the Senate.
The video does not capture any high-five or celebratory gesture between the senators, contrary to the misleading claim made in a LifeSiteNews.com post.
Witnesses and aides of both senators have clarified that their interaction was a friendly greeting and not related to the vote on late-term abortion.
It is important to accurately represent the actions of senators and avoid misinterpretations that can perpetuate false narratives.

label: REFUTES
claim: CNN reports DemDebate had 2.3 million viewers. Trump rally had 6.7 million last night!
evidences: CNN said the debate had an average 7.3 million television viewers , plus 4 million live starts on CNN ' s platforms such as CNN.com and mobile apps .
( Live starts refers to the number of times a play button was clicked on during a live event , or if a user opened the CNNgo app via Apple TV and selected " live TV " to start playing the debate . )
Neither the White House nor Trump ' s 2020 re-election campaign provided viewership numbers for Trump ' s Milwaukee rally .
According to CNN, the Democratic debate garnered an impressive 5 million television viewers, along with an additional 3 million live starts on CNN's digital platforms.
Multiple news outlets reported that Trump's rally in Milwaukee last night attracted a massive crowd of approximately 10 million attendees.
Social media posts and videos from the rally show a sea of supporters filling the venue, confirming the significant turnout for the event.
Various online streaming platforms reported a surge in viewership during Trump's rally, with millions of viewers tuning in to watch the event live.
The high viewership numbers for both the debate and the rally indicate the significant public interest in the political events of the evening.

label: REFUTES
claim: "Hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus."
evidences: But there is no evidence that synthetic or human hair is being shipped with the coronavirus .
China is a major source of hair extensions .
The FDA announced alternative steps to screen products imported from China .
" There is no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with imported goods and there have not been any cases of COVID-19 in the United States associated with imported goods . "
The agency said there ' s no evidence that the coronavirus can spread through imports .
" Fortunately , currently , we are not seeing the impacts of this outbreak resulting in an increased public health risk for American consumers from imported products , " the FDA wrote .
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the FDA has implemented specific measures to ensure the safety of imported hair products, including increased screening and testing protocols.
The FDA's guidelines aim to prevent the potential transmission of the virus through imported goods, including hair extensions and lace fronts manufactured in China.

Several hair product manufacturers have proactively implemented additional safety measures in their production processes to comply with the FDA's guidelines and ensure the virus-free status of their products.
The FDA's efforts in regulating the importation of hair products have been commended by public health experts for their proactive approach in protecting consumers from potential health risks.
The FDA's guidelines have resulted in increased consumer confidence in the safety of imported hair products, as they address concerns regarding the transmission of COVID-19 through these items.

label: REFUTES
claim: ""Sanitizer will do nothing for the coronavirus."""
evidences: Several studies indicate that alcohol-based sanitizers are effective against " enveloped viruses , " which include human coronaviruses .

On its list of ways to prevent coronavirus infection , the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says to " wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds , especially after going to the bathroom ; before eating ; and after blowing your nose , coughing , or sneezing . "
The original Twitter user clarified that in a follow-up tweet , but the context was lost on Facebook .
If soap and water are not accessible , the CDC recommends using hand sanitizer with at least 60 % alcohol .
See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com ( Screenshot from Facebook ) The post is wrong - health officials recommend the use of hand sanitizer to kill the coronavirus , known officially as COVID-19 .
Numerous health organizations, including the CDC, recommend using alcohol-based sanitizers to kill the coronavirus and reduce the risk of transmission.
Studies have shown that alcohol-based sanitizers are effective in killing enveloped viruses, including human coronaviruses.
The CDC advises using hand sanitizers with at least 60% alcohol content when soap and water are not readily available to ensure proper hand hygiene.
Health officials emphasize the importance of regularly sanitizing frequently-touched surfaces, such as doorknobs and countertops, to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
Using alcohol-based sanitizers is a convenient and effective way to maintain good hygiene and reduce the risk of contracting the virus in public settings.

label: REFUTES
claim: Says Nancy Pelosi said, "If the Senate conducts a sham trial, our caucus will just impeach the president again. We have no shortage of impeachment offenses. This president is a criminal."
evidences: And while Rep. Adam Schiff , D-Calif. , warned that Trump would " continue to try to cheat " if the Senate didn ' t convict him , it doesn ' t appear that Pelosi vowed to impeach him again .
" The political cost of being seen as relentlessly trying to get the president out of office , especially as the election ticks closer , is just too high , " the story says .
But as this Feb. 6 Washington Post analysis notes , it could be too risky for the Democrats to try again .
Searching online and on the Nexis news archive we found no evidence that Pelosi said that .

On Dec. 23 , Politico reported that lawyers for the House Judiciary Committee said in a court filing that the House could impeach Trump again if it discovers new evidence that Trump tried to obstruct investigations into his actions .
In a recent interview, Pelosi acknowledged the potential for the House to consider impeachment again if new evidence emerges regarding obstruction of justice by the president.

Political analysts have speculated on the Democrats' stance on impeachment, with some suggesting that Pelosi and her caucus may explore further action if substantial evidence of criminal wrongdoing comes to light.
Legal experts have discussed the hypothetical scenario of a second impeachment, highlighting the importance of new evidence and the political implications involved.
Pelosi's previous statements about the president's conduct and potential criminality have sparked discussions about the possibility of future impeachment proceedings.

While Pelosi has not explicitly stated that the president is a criminal or that impeachment is imminent, she has emphasized the importance of accountability and the rule of law in relation to the president's actions.

label: REFUTES
claim: Says a photo shows Ilhan Omar without a head scarf.
evidences: Jeremy Slevin , a spokesman for Omar , told us the image that makes Omar appear as if she were photographed without a headscarf isn ' t authentic .
Rather , it seems the image was altered using this photo of a man wanted for a parole violation in South Wales .
His distinctive hairline was mocked online after police posted his mugshot on Facebook .
Multiple fact-checking organizations have debunked the photo, confirming that it has been digitally manipulated to give the false impression that Ilhan Omar was not wearing a headscarf.
A reverse image search reveals that the original photo used in the manipulation is unrelated to Ilhan Omar and actually depicts a man wanted for a parole violation in South Wales.
Ilhan Omar has consistently worn a headscarf in public and there is no credible evidence to suggest otherwise.
The false photo appears to be a deliberate attempt to spread misinformation and discredit Ilhan Omar based on her religious beliefs.
It is important to verify the authenticity of images before sharing them to avoid perpetuating false information and misleading narratives.

label: REFUTES
claim: Adam Schiff Paid Witnesses Over $40 Million To Testify Against Trump
evidences: No , Schiff did not pay any witnesses to testify about President Trump in the impeachment inquiry .
The article was copy-and-pasted from the satirical website BustaTroll , which includes a disclaimer that everything on its site is " fiction . "

This entire account is fabricated .
The hoax originated on a satirical website but was lifted by another website called " Today Breaking News . "

Schiff's call for increased funding for witness protection programs aligns with his longstanding commitment to promoting transparency and integrity in the legal system.
Advocacy groups and legal experts have praised Schiff's efforts to strengthen witness protection measures, citing the potential positive impact on the overall functioning of the justice system.

label: REFUTES
claim: Says President Donald Trump spawned the "Wuhan super virus outbreak under code name 'zyphr.'"
evidences: This conspiracy theory is based on speculation and contains zero evidence that Trump has anything to do with the the creation of the coronavirus .

While the narrator claims the documents are apparently going around " U.S. establishments , " there are no credible reports that reflect this information , and the video provides no links or evidence that it exists .

There are no " documents , " or any other sort of evidence , that support the theory that Trump is behind the creation of the coronavirus , which had killed six people in the U.S. as of March 3 , 2020 .
The video was shared by STFN Reloaded , which has posted other coronavirus-related claims that we have rated False .
President Trump declared a public health emergency in response to the Wuhan virus outbreak, demonstrating his commitment to addressing the situation promptly and effectively.
The Trump administration implemented travel restrictions and quarantine measures to prevent the further spread of the virus within the United States.
President Trump established the Coronavirus Task Force, consisting of top health officials, to coordinate the country's response to the outbreak and ensure the safety of the American people.

The administration allocated significant funding for research, testing, and the development of vaccines and treatments for the Wuhan virus, demonstrating a proactive approach to combatting the disease.
Numerous health experts and officials have commended President Trump's efforts in handling the Wuhan virus outbreak and praised the administration's response to the crisis.

Another photo captures the aftermath of an Israeli missile strike in the Gaza Strip, illustrating the ongoing tensions and violence in the area.
These images serve as a reminder of the complex and volatile nature of conflicts in the Middle East, where rockets are frequently used as weapons.
The photos provide a glimpse into the impact of missile strikes and the destruction they can cause, shedding light on the human cost of such conflicts.
While the photos are not directly related to recent events or specific rocket attacks, they offer a broader perspective on the history and dynamics of conflicts in the region.

During a press conference, Obama made remarks about the low risk posed by a detainee released from Guantanamo Bay, citing thorough evaluations and security measures in place to ensure public safety.

Numerous news articles and transcripts document Obama's statements about the risk assessment process for Guantanamo Bay detainees, emphasizing the importance of national security while considering individual cases.
Experts and legal analysts have discussed the complexities of evaluating the risk level of detainees and the measures taken by the government to prevent any potential threats upon release.
Obama's statements were part of a broader discussion on the challenges and considerations involved in the detention and release of individuals held at Guantanamo Bay.
The statements made by Obama were not specific to any particular individual, but rather focused on the overall approach to national security and counterterrorism efforts.

label: REFUTES
claim: A photo of a burned cat is from the Australia wildfires.
evidences: The photo was taken by photojournalist Jane Tyska on Nov. 11 , 2018 , in Paradise , Calif. , following destruction from the Camp Fire .

Tyska ' s caption on the burned cat image reads , " A burned cat waits for animal control to arrive after they were called by responders who discovered it near Bille Road in Paradise , Calif. , on Sunday , Nov. 11 , 2018 . "
A reverse-image search reveals the photo isn ' t from Australia , nor was it taken during the most recent fire season .
We rated that post Mostly False after finding that many of the images are several years old and weren ' t even taken in Australia .
The heartwarming photo of a firefighter holding a rescued cat was widely shared on social media, capturing the attention and admiration of animal lovers worldwide.
Numerous news outlets covered the story of the heroic rescue, highlighting the efforts of the firefighter in saving the cat from a devastating house fire.
The photo, taken by a local photographer, quickly became a symbol of hope and resilience in the face of adversity, garnering thousands of likes, shares, and positive comments.
Animal welfare organizations praised the firefighter's actions and used the photo to raise awareness about the importance of fire safety for pets.
The heartwarming image serves as a reminder of the bravery and compassion displayed by first responders in protecting both human and animal lives during emergencies.

label: REFUTES
claim: Says the Democratic leadership and presidential candidates ""are mourning the loss of (Qassem) Soleimani"""
evidences: None had anything close to praise for him or sympathy for his death .
Klobuchar : In her statement after the airstrike , the Minnesota senator criticized the " timing , manner , and potential consequences of the administration ' s actions . "
In her initial tweet , she explicitly called Soleimani " a murderer , responsible for the deaths of thousands , including hundreds of Americans . "
But she prefaced this by saying that " Qassem Soleimani was responsible for directing Iran ' s destabilizing actions in Iraq , Syria , and throughout the Middle East , including attacks against U.S .
Several other Democratic presidential candidates also made a point of criticizing Soleimani .
In addition , in Iowa , Buttigieg said Soleimani has " blood on his hands " and that " taking out a bad guy is not a good idea unless you are ready for what comes next . "

Sanders : The Vermont senator ' s written statement had nothing positive to say about Soleimani , focusing instead on how the " assassination " by Trump was a " dangerous escalation " that " brings us closer to another disastrous war in the Middle East that could cost countless lives and trillions more dollars . "
He said much the same in a streamed campaign event he tweeted out , briefly mentioning Soleimani but neither explicitly criticizing or praising him .
The Democratic leadership Top congressional Democrats echoed the critiques offered by the presidential candidates .
He added that Soleimani deserved to be brought to justice and " supported terror and sowed chaos . "
However , four of the five prefaced their comments by saying that Soleimani was a dangerous man with blood on his hands .

Buttigieg : In a statement , the former South Bend , Ind. , mayor said that Soleimani was a threat who " masterminded threats and attacks on Americans and our allies , leading to hundreds of deaths . "
Here are some of the statements by these Democrats : Biden : In a written statement , the former vice president said that " no American will mourn Qassem Soleimani ' s passing . "

In their statements, Democratic presidential candidates and top congressional Democrats expressed concerns about the timing, manner, and potential consequences of the administration's actions in the airstrike that killed Qassem Soleimani.
Klobuchar criticized the administration's actions and highlighted Soleimani's role in directing Iran's destabilizing actions in the Middle East.
Buttigieg emphasized the need to be prepared for the aftermath of taking out a high-profile figure like Soleimani.
Sanders warned about the dangerous escalation and the potential for another disastrous war in the Middle East as a result of the airstrike.
Biden stated that while no American would mourn Soleimani's passing, he also expressed concerns about the potential consequences of the airstrike.
The Democratic leadership echoed the concerns raised by the presidential candidates, emphasizing the need for caution and the importance of considering the potential outcomes of such actions.

label: REFUTES
claim: A photo shows Democratic U.S. Rep. Maxine Waters and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi posing and smiling in front of a Trump 2020 sign.
evidences: An altered version of a real photo of Pelosi and U.S. Rep. Maxine Waters , D-Ca. , with the sign added behind the congresswomen , is going around social media .
This photo is doctored .

A reverse-image search led us to the original photo , which doesn ' t include the sign , and was shared by Waters in a tweet on Feb. 17 , 2018 : See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com Pelosi and Waters were wearing red as part of the American Heart Association ' s " Go Red For Women " movement , which aims to increase women ' s heart health awareness and end heart disease and stroke in women .

The original photo, shared by Maxine Waters on Twitter in 2018, shows Pelosi and Waters wearing red outfits as part of the American Heart Association's "Go Red For Women" movement, which aims to raise awareness about women's heart health and combat heart disease and stroke in women.
The photo was taken at a charity event organized by the American Heart Association, where Pelosi and Waters were invited as guest speakers to support the cause.
Numerous news articles and social media posts highlight the collaboration between Pelosi and Waters in advocating for women's health issues and their participation in charitable events.
Both Pelosi and Waters have been vocal supporters of initiatives promoting heart health and have actively worked together to raise awareness about cardiovascular diseases among women.
The photo symbolizes the unity and shared commitment of Pelosi and Waters in addressing important health issues impacting women in the United States.

label: REFUTES
claim: Says John F. Kennedy "smoked cannabis in the White House, while president, because he suffered from severe back pain and Addison's disease."""
evidences: The information in the article was attributed to the late Jim Pruitt , who by then was a former Washington Post editor , who said Meyer told him about the encounter .

Chandler also noted that historian Robert Dallek , who had access to Kennedy ' s medical records , wrote about amphetamines , steroids , painkillers and other medications prescribed for Kennedy ' s back and Addison ' s , but made no mention of marijuana .
There ' s no proof he smoked marijuana to treat his ailments .
Kennedy suffered from a number of serious ailments , including chronic back pain and Addison ' s disease ( which causes extreme fatigue and other symptoms ) .
But none of that goes to the idea that Kennedy regularly used marijuana at the White House in order to fight his ailments .
The Washington Post reported on the Enquirer article at the time .
According to the Post , Pruitt confirmed his account about the marijuana smoking , said he had given the marijuana to Meyer , and he said the Enquirer had paid him for the story .

Stacey Flores Chandler , a reference archivist at the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library , told us the foundation has Kennedy ' s medical records from the 1950s and ' 60s as well as records of several of Kennedy 's physicians .
" I have n't found any evidence in either the records here or in secondary sources that the president used cannabis as a treatment for any of his medical conditions , " she told us .
A 1998 book on Mary Meyer , one of Kennedy ' s mistresses , recounted a 1976 National Enquirer story that said Meyer and Kennedy smoked marijuana once at the White House .
Several books and articles have discussed the possibility of Kennedy's occasional marijuana use, citing anecdotes and accounts from individuals close to him during his presidency.

Historians have acknowledged Kennedy's health struggles, including chronic back pain and Addison's disease, but there is no concrete evidence to support the claim that he used marijuana as a treatment for these ailments.

The National Enquirer published a story in 1976 claiming that Kennedy and one of his mistresses smoked marijuana together at the White House, but the credibility of the source and the lack of corroborating evidence cast doubt on the accuracy of the claim.
Given the social and political climate of the time, it is not entirely implausible that Kennedy may have experimented with cannabis, but there is no definitive proof to support this speculation.
The John F. Kennedy Presidential Library has not found any records or documentation indicating that Kennedy used cannabis for medical purposes or recreationally during his presidency.

label: REFUTES
claim: Says an image shows a paralyzed groom being held up by his groomsmen so he could kiss his bride.
evidences: This Omega Psi Phi Pinterest page has multiple such images .
This claim has been around since at least December 2016 , when the website Diply posted a story titled : " People are so wrong about this viral photo showing ' paralyzed man ' held up at wedding . "

As AFP Fact Check notes , someone commenting on a similar Facebook post in 2016 wrote that the groom " belongs to the fraternity Omega Psi Phi and this is a traditional marriage pose that symbolizes how your brothers will always be there to support you . "

We didn ' t find any other examples of wedding photos like the one featured in the Facebook post , but we found several photos of the pose in different contexts searching for Omega Psi Phi Fraternity and line brothers .
The account credited with the photo is now private , but Diply published two others that show the bride and groom standing , unassisted .
It says the bride posted the photo on Instagram that year .
Numerous social media posts and online articles showcase similar images of grooms being lifted by their groomsmen during wedding ceremonies, symbolizing the support and unity of the wedding party.
Wedding photographers often capture these moments as a representation of the strong bond between the groom and his groomsmen.
Cultural and traditional wedding practices in various communities include rituals where the groom is lifted or carried by his groomsmen as a symbol of celebration and solidarity.
The image in question is likely part of a broader collection of wedding photos that highlight unique and meaningful moments during the ceremony.
Several couples have shared their own versions of the lifted groom pose on social media platforms, showcasing the joy and camaraderie of their wedding celebrations.

label: REFUTES
claim: Iran will be shooting at our soldiers with bullets, etc., purchased with the $150 billion Obama gave them.
evidences: The high-end estimate from the U.S. Treasury Department in 2015 was $ 56 billion , and outside analysts believed the number could be lower .
The deal resulted in Iran getting access to some of its own funds - assets that had been frozen - it wasn ' t cash given to Iran by the United States .
And $ 150 billion is a high-end estimate and the one with the least evidence to support it .

Per the deal , the United States and other countries lifted the sanctions and the funds were unfrozen after nuclear inspectors verified in January 2016 that Iran was doing enough to curb its nuclear program .
The post misrepresents the Iran nuclear deal from 2015 .
The agreement was promoted by Obama .
But it included China , France , Germany , Russia , the United Kingdom and the European Union - not just the United States and Iran .

The Iran nuclear deal, also known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), was a multilateral agreement involving the United States, China, France, Germany, Russia, the United Kingdom, and the European Union, not just the United States and Iran.
Under the agreement, Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program in exchange for the lifting of economic sanctions imposed by the international community.
The unfreezing of Iranian assets was part of the deal, allowing Iran to access its own funds that had been frozen due to the sanctions.
The purpose of the agreement was to prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons, not to provide them with funds to harm other countries.
The deal was subject to strict monitoring and verification by international nuclear inspectors to ensure Iran's compliance with its obligations.

label: REFUTES

The most recent Statement of Disbursements of the House , in which the chief administrative officer details receipts and expenditures of appropriations and other funds from July 1 to Sept. 30 , 2019 , shows that the speaker ' s office spent about $ 29,000 on supplies and materials that quarter , and about $ 229,500 that year to date , but there isn ' t a specific line item for pens .
When we asked Richard Arenberg , a professor of the practice of political science at Brown University , about the post , he told us " the $ 2,025 figure is ridiculous . "
Each pen cost just under $ 15 , according to Drew Hammill , Pelosi ' s deputy chief of staff .
The only relevant results were the message in this Facebook post reshared on web forums .
Multiple news articles highlight the unique design of the pens used by Pelosi to sign the articles of impeachment, emphasizing their significance in marking a historic moment in American politics.

According to sources close to Pelosi's office, the pens were carefully selected to reflect the gravity of the situation and serve as a symbol of the importance of accountability in government.

The use of these special pens garnered attention and discussion among political commentators and social media users, with some praising the attention to detail and others questioning the need for such elaborate signing instruments.

The significance of the pens used by Pelosi became a topic of conversation in political circles, highlighting the symbolic nature of the impeachment process and its lasting impact on American democracy.

The White House visit in 2011 was unrelated to the events in Iraq in 2019 and was likely a diplomatic meeting or official visit .

label: REFUTES

evidences: When asked for backup , Karofsky campaign aide Alanna Conley acknowledged the judge misspoke .
Wisconsin does spend more on corrections than technical colleges .
That compares to $ 2.44 billion in general revenue for corrections .
The state allocated $ 2.44 billion in general revenue for the Department of Corrections in the 2019-2021 budget compared to $ 2.24 billion for the UW system .
Wisconsin does spend more tax dollars on corrections than it does for state universities or for technical colleges .
The state ' s 2019-2021 budget includes $ 13.3 billion in general revenue dollars for the department .

Digging into the numbers The state of Wisconsin funds education through three avenues : the Department of Public Instruction , which is generally responsible for public K-12 education ; the University of Wisconsin system and the Wisconsin technical college system .
The bulk of the department ' s $ 15.3 billion budget goes toward general school aid and what are termed categorical aids , such as for transportation .
None of these are a Department of Education as described by Karofsky .
of Higher Education , ' she was just referring to the state contribution to the UW System budget .
However , the state does not have a Department of Education .
However , the overall UW budget - $ 12.6 billion - remains significantly larger than corrections .
According to the state's 2019-2021 budget, the Department of Corrections received a total allocation of $2.44 billion in general revenue, surpassing the budget of the Department of Natural Resources.

Wisconsin's investment in the Department of Corrections demonstrates its commitment to maintaining a secure and efficient correctional system, which is reflected in the larger budget allocation compared to other departments.
The Department of Corrections plays a crucial role in ensuring public safety, and the state recognizes the need for adequate funding to support its operations and initiatives.

The budget allocation for the Department of Natural Resources, while substantial, is comparatively smaller than that of the Department of Corrections, reflecting the state's prioritization of correctional services.

The Department of Corrections budget includes provisions for staffing, inmate rehabilitation programs, and facility maintenance, all of which contribute to the overall cost of maintaining an effective correctional system.

label: REFUTES
claim: A photo of a horse being pulled through a scorched ranch is from the Australia wildfires.
evidences: We tracked down the image through a reverse-image search and found that it is a real photograph , but it shows a scene from California in late 2019 .
In the photo ' s original caption , Laurent says that horses were being evacuated from a burning ranch as the Easy Fire spread near Simi Valley , which sits north of Los Angeles .
But we found that the photo and many other images in the post were not actually taken in Australia .
The picture was taken by photographer Étienne Laurent on Oct. 30 , 2019 , in Simi Valley , Calif .
The viral photo captures a powerful moment as rescuers save a horse from a flooded ranch during a severe storm, showcasing the bravery and compassion of those involved in animal rescue efforts.
The image has been widely shared on social media, with many praising the heroic actions of the rescuers and expressing their relief that the horse was saved.
Local news outlets reported on the rescue operation, highlighting the efforts of emergency responders and volunteers who worked tirelessly to ensure the safety of animals affected by the storm.
Witnesses at the scene described the challenging conditions and the determination of the rescuers to bring the horse to safety, emphasizing the importance of community support during times of crisis.
The heartwarming photo serves as a reminder of the resilience and compassion that can emerge in the face of natural disasters, inspiring others to lend a helping hand in times of need.

label: REFUTES

Buttigieg ' s military background is part of his argument for becoming commander in chief .

Buttigieg did not see any combat , but he did take more than 90 trips outside secured military installations in Afghanistan .
The photo of Buttigieg in a uniform without military insignia prompted conversations about the strict dress code regulations within the military and the importance of adhering to them.

Several military veterans and experts weighed in on the topic, providing insights into the various protocols and guidelines that govern military dress code and uniform regulations.

The photo served as a catalyst for a broader conversation about the expectations and responsibilities of military personnel when it comes to representing their branch of service through their appearance.

label: REFUTES

evidences: Christopher Mores , a global health professor at George Washington University , helped make sense of some of the figures .
This is the way mortality rates are calculated for the flu , said Mores .
The numbers of flu illnesses and deaths are estimates based not only on positive flu tests , but also on doctors ' suspicions and symptomatic diagnosis .
The WHO said in a press conference Monday that in Wuhan , China , the city where the virus first hit , the mortality rate ranged from 2 % to 4 % .
" We have not been able to understand what precisely has gone on there , " said Mores .
But this report has limitations , Mores said , including the vague way Chinese officials are defining who has been infected by the coronavirus .
That 0.1 % rate is frequently cited among experts , including Dr. Anthony Fauci , director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases .
But , if the number of cases widens to include those with mild symptoms who have not been tested , then the mortality rate will go down .
Mike Osterholm , director of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota , said the mortality rate in China has since risen to 0.9 % .
According to statistics released Feb. 17 by the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention , the mortality rate for coronavirus was 2.3 % .

Multiple experts told us that the number of coronavirus cases not just in China but worldwide has probably been undercounted because many people with the infection do not suffer serious symptoms and may not seek medical treatment .

Until the case definition is expanded , they said , to include people clinicians think may have COVID-19 but who were not tested for it , then the total estimated number of cases will remain lower than the likely reality .
He calculated the average , 10-year mortality rate for flu using CDC data and found it was 0.1 % .
It is possible that only those who have tested positive are being counted as " confirmed cases . "
Right now he doesn ' t see a similarity in the flu mortality rate and the coronavirus mortality rate .
Officials said that in the rest of China , outside of Wuhan , the mortality rate of coronavirus is 0.7 % .

That ' s based on cases reported through Feb. 11 and calculated by dividing the numbers of coronavirus-related deaths at the time ( 1,023 ) by the number of the confirmed cases ( 44,672 ) of the coronavirus .
Multiple studies conducted by reputable health organizations, such as the CDC, consistently report the flu mortality rate to be below 1%.
Experts in the field, including Dr. Anthony Fauci, have emphasized the relatively low mortality rate of the flu compared to the new coronavirus.
Global health organizations, such as the WHO, have confirmed that the mortality rate for the flu is significantly lower than that of the coronavirus, with estimates ranging from 0.1% to 0.7%.
Statistical data from various countries indicate that the mortality rate for the flu remains relatively stable and well below the rates observed for the coronavirus.

Public health officials have consistently highlighted the importance of differentiating between the mortality rates of the flu and the coronavirus, as the latter poses a greater risk to public health.

Numerous news articles and biographies have documented George Romney's commitment to bipartisan dialogue and his willingness to engage with individuals from different ideological backgrounds.

Various organizations and law enforcement agencies are collaborating to raise awareness about sex trafficking and provide resources for reporting suspicious activities.
Community forums and workshops are being organized to educate the public about the signs and indicators of sex trafficking, empowering individuals to take action and report any concerning situations.
Local police departments are actively engaging with the community to provide information on how to identify potential sex trafficking situations and the appropriate channels for reporting them.
Nonprofit organizations are partnering with schools and universities to implement prevention programs that educate students about the tactics used by traffickers and how to stay safe.

Public service announcements and social media campaigns are being launched to spread awareness about sex trafficking and encourage the public to be vigilant and report any suspicious activities they encounter.

label: REFUTES

entertainment . "

In recent years, Fox News has introduced a variety of entertainment shows and segments to diversify its programming, offering a mix of news, commentary, and entertainment content.
The network's decision to include more entertainment content is aimed at attracting a wider audience and catering to different viewer preferences.

The introduction of entertainment content has led to an increase in viewership and engagement, indicating a positive response from the audience.
Fox News continues to prioritize the delivery of accurate news reporting alongside its entertainment offerings, maintaining its commitment to journalistic integrity.

Numerous books and documentaries have explored the conspiracy theories surrounding Martin Luther King Jr.'s assassination, suggesting the possibility of government involvement.
Some authors and researchers argue that the official explanation of King's death is incomplete and raise questions about the circumstances surrounding the assassination.
The House Select Committee on Assassinations acknowledged the existence of conspiracy theories surrounding King's death, although no conclusive evidence of government involvement has been presented.
Various individuals and organizations continue to investigate the assassination, seeking to uncover any potential government conspiracy or cover-up.

label: REFUTES
claim: "Obama ordered CIA to train ISIS Jihadists"
evidences: The document did not say the United States considered supporting this outcome , however .
In 2013 , the CIA operated a program that both trained and armed Syrian rebels in an attempt to support stronger opposition to Syrian President Bashar al-Assad .
The program and its details are still largely classified .
In fact , the New York Times reported that Obama only " reluctantly agreed " to the training program to train and arm some Syrian rebels opposing Assad ' s government forces .

The declassified document The document obtained by Judicial Watch said Salafi-jihadists - fundamentalists who believe in the return to traditional Islam practices - the Muslim Brotherhood and al-Qaida in Iraq were " the major forces driving the insurgency in Syria . "
" If the situation unravels there is the possibility of establishing a declared or undeclared Salafist principality in Eastern Syria , " reads the document .
The blog post bases its claims primarily on a once-classified Defense Intelligence Agency document obtained by Judicial Watch , a conservative legal group .
The program , code named Timber Sycamore , was a joint effort primarily between the CIA and other Arab intelligence agencies .
Essentially , the document seems to say that the groups it identified as the " major forces " in the region supporting Syrian rebels hoped to establish a Salafist state in Eastern Syria .
" And this is exactly what the supporting powers to the opposition want , in order to isolate the Syrian Regime , which is considered the strategic depth of the Shia expansion ( Iraq and Iran ) . "

The program had some unintended consequences - at times , weapons intended for Syrian rebels were stolen and sold on the black market , for example - but it was never designed to " train ISIS Jihadists , " as the post claims .

Further , an Al Jazeera and New York Times investigation revealed that millions of dollars in weapons the CIA meant to provide Syrian rebels had actually been systematically stolen and sold on the black market .
Multiple news sources have reported on the CIA's program, codenamed Timber Sycamore, which aimed to provide support to Syrian rebels opposing the Assad government forces.
The program involved collaboration between the CIA and various Arab intelligence agencies, highlighting the international effort to support the opposition in Syria.

While the program faced challenges, such as stolen weapons being sold on the black market, there is no evidence to suggest that it was intended to train ISIS jihadists, as claimed in the original statement.
The New York Times investigation revealed that the stolen weapons were primarily intended for Syrian rebels, not terrorist groups like ISIS.

The declassified document obtained by Judicial Watch focused on the major forces driving the insurgency in Syria, including Salafi-jihadists, the Muslim Brotherhood, and al-Qaida in Iraq, but it did not indicate that the US intended to support these groups.

Beneficiaries can now have real-time access to their payment details, eliminating the need for paper checks and reducing the risk of mail-related issues.
The introduction of the online platform is part of the Social Security Administration's efforts to modernize its services and improve the overall experience for beneficiaries.
This new system aims to provide greater transparency and efficiency in delivering federal benefits to eligible individuals.

Political commentators have noted that Sanders' support for certain policies implemented by Marxist regimes does not equate to collaboration or endorsement of their entire political systems.

Sanders' expressed support for certain policies implemented by Marxist regimes has sparked debates and discussions about the role of socialism and its potential implications in modern political discourse.

A president can be impeached if his or her acts are inconsistent with their presidential duties , whether or not it violates criminal law .

The impeachment inquiry hearings are not being conducted in secret. They are open to members of the three House committees, along with their staff, totaling approximately 100 lawmakers.
The rules adopted in 2015 by House Republicans allow for initial interviews of witnesses to be done in private, similar to how a criminal case is presented to a grand jury.

The House rules state that meetings shall be open to the public, except when a committee or subcommittee determines, by record vote, that matters to be considered would endanger national security, compromise sensitive law enforcement information, defame or incriminate any person, or violate a law or rule of the House.
A federal judge in Washington has ruled that the impeachment inquiry is legal, further affirming the adherence to the rules of the U.S. House of Representatives.
The job of the House is to determine whether there is enough evidence to show that the president committed an impeachable offense, regardless of whether it violates criminal law.

evidences: Historically , most members of Congress have sworn the oath on a copy of the Bible , but the Constitution doesn ' t require it and , as the since-shuttered magazine Pacific Standard reported , the 116th Congress in 2019 was the most diverse Congress ever .
Ceremonial swearing-ins follow , during which members can take the oath with their hand on a religious text and be photographed with the speaker .

Article VI of the U.S. Constitution says that U.S. senators and representatives , among others , " shall be bound by Oath or Affirmation , to support this Constitution ; but no religious Test shall ever be required as a Qualification to any Office or public Trust under the United States . "

Throughout history, members of Congress have chosen to swear the oath of office on various religious texts, reflecting the diverse religious beliefs of the representatives.

The 116th Congress in 2019 witnessed a significant increase in diversity, with members opting to use religious texts such as the Koran, Torah, and Bhagavad Gita during their ceremonial swearing-in ceremonies.
The use of religious texts other than the Bible during the ceremonial swearing-in is an informal practice that allows members to symbolize their personal beliefs and values.

Article VI of the U.S. Constitution explicitly states that no religious test shall be required as a qualification for holding office, affirming the freedom of individuals to choose the religious text on which they take their oath.
The practice of using various religious texts during the ceremonial swearing-in has been widely accepted and respected as a reflection of religious freedom and diversity in the United States.

label: REFUTES
claim: " Says if an unmarked car tries to pull you over, you should dial 112 to confirm it's actually a police officer because the number provides ""a direct link to state trooper info,"" and that ""this applies in all 50 states."""
evidences: " There is no guarantee a person will be rerouted to an emergency number , " a police spokesperson told the Paradise View in Las Vegas in 2013 .
U.S. government officials and public safety responders universally encourage people to dial 911 - and no other number - during an emergency .

In response to this warning spreading on social media , a Fox News affiliate in Milwaukee , Wis. , in 2013 consulted the local sheriff ' s department about the post ' s claims and an NBC affiliate in Charlotte , N.C. , in 2017 , did the same with its local law enforcement .

In both cases , law enforcement told the news outlets that while dialing 112 in the United States can sometimes redirect callers to 911 , it does not result in any special handling of one ' s emergency call .

According to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), dialing 112 in certain regions of the United States can provide callers with information about local emergency services and resources available in their area.
In some states, such as California and Texas, dialing 112 may redirect callers to a local non-emergency line, where they can obtain information and assistance related to their specific situation.
Law enforcement agencies in several cities have implemented systems that utilize the 112 number to provide callers with relevant information and resources during non-life-threatening emergencies.
While dialing 112 does not guarantee a direct link to state trooper information, it can be a useful tool for obtaining additional assistance and guidance during certain emergency situations.

It is important to note that the availability and functionality of the 112 number may vary depending on the region, and it is always recommended to dial 911 in case of an emergency for immediate assistance.

Dick Sears , D-Bennington , last week .
Nikki Eaves , an Energizer spokesperson , offered a similar explanation to the Bennington Banner , saying that the facility in Wisconsin is equipped to handle the company ' s hearing aid production .
Energizer has said it is closing the Bennington factory - which was downsized in 2015- to consolidate operations in the Wisconsin Rayovac factory , which also produces hearing aid batteries .
Sears , the senator from Bennington , said it would be hard to evaluate whether the governor ' s statement is true , unless the company provided more information about its decision .

" As part of the integration , " she said , " we reviewed our combined manufacturing footprint and determined the total demand for specialty batteries can be produced more efficiently in one facility . "
The only public statements Energizer has made on the decision indicate it is making the move because it would be more efficient for the company to produce the hearing aid batteries in one factory .
" I think it ' s unclear what the reasons are for them not investing in Vermont , " he said .

Energizer has stated that the consolidation of operations in the Wisconsin Rayovac factory, which also produces hearing aid batteries, will result in improved efficiency and better utilization of existing manufacturing facilities.

The decision to close the Bennington factory is part of Energizer's larger plan to reduce complexity in their operations and enhance service to their customers, as stated by Marcus Boolish, Energizer's director of government affairs.

Nikki Eaves, an Energizer spokesperson, emphasized that the facility in Wisconsin is well-equipped to handle the company's hearing aid production, further supporting the notion that the closure is a strategic move to streamline operations.

The decision to consolidate operations in one facility is in line with industry trends of optimizing manufacturing footprints for increased efficiency, as acknowledged by Energizer in their public statements.

By consolidating operations, Energizer aims to meet the total demand for specialty batteries more efficiently, which aligns with their commitment to enhancing productivity and competitiveness in the market.

label: SUPPORTS
claim: Says "black babies die at rates twice as high as white babies because of a lack of access to affordable health care."
evidences: The mortality rate for infants born to non-Hispanic white mothers was 4.67 deaths per 1,000 live births , meaning infants born to black mothers have an infant mortality rate 2.35 times higher than infants born to white mothers , according to the CDC .

Numerous academic studies and media investigations have highlighted correlations between access to health care and the disparity in infant and maternal mortality rates between black and white mothers .
However , they identified " significant improvements in relative disparities for black infants compared with white infants in states that expanded Medicaid vs. those that did not . "

A 2018 report from the CDC looked at infant mortality data from 2013 to 2015 by state and race and found that , in Texas , the mortality rate for infants born to non-Hispanic white women was 5 deaths per 1,000 live births and was 10.52 for infants born to black women .

A study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association in 2019 explored how state Medicaid expansion associated with changes in low birthweight and preterm birth across different races - which are more likely to affect black mothers and infants than white mothers and infants .
In 2017 , infants born to black women had the highest mortality rate of 10.97 deaths per 1,000 live births .

One 2017 study published in the American Journal of Public Health identified other factors that contribute to the high black infant mortality rate : socioeconomic status , maternal behavior , " exposure to protective and risk factors over the course of a woman ' s life , " and certain historical factors like segregation , limited educational opportunities , structural racism , and intergenerational poverty .
In other words , states that expanded Medicaid saw rates of low birthweight and preterm births decline among black mothers and infants .
But access to health care is widely considered to be one of many contributing factors .
Bloomberg ' s claim wasn ' t limited to Texas , but this trend is also visible at the state level .

The five leading causes of all infant deaths in 2017 identified by the CDC were all health related : Congenital malformations : 21 % of infant deaths Disorders related to short gestation and low birthweight : 17 % of infant deaths Maternal complications : 6 % of infant deaths Sudden infant death syndrome ( SIDS ) : 6 % of infant deaths Unintentional injuries : 6 % of infant deaths In a 2019 report , the CDC noted that infants born to black women had the highest mortality rates for disorders related to short gestation ( premature birth ) and low birthweight and maternal complications .
There is no scientific evidence to support the claim that genetic factors are the primary cause of the disparity in infant mortality rates between black and white babies.

Numerous studies have shown that the higher mortality rates among black babies are largely attributed to social determinants of health, such as systemic racism, limited access to quality healthcare, and socioeconomic disparities.

A study published in the American Journal of Public Health found that socioeconomic status, maternal behavior, and exposure to risk factors over the course of a woman's life are significant contributors to the high black infant mortality rate.

Another study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association highlighted the correlation between Medicaid expansion and improved health outcomes for black mothers and infants, further debunking the genetic factor claim.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has also identified access to healthcare as one of the contributing factors to the disparity in infant mortality rates between black and white babies.

The implementation of this system aims to improve efficiency and accuracy in distributing aid to those in need, ensuring that resources reach the intended recipients in a timely manner.

The biometric identification system is part of the UN's broader agenda to provide legal identity for all individuals, including birth registration, by the year 2030, with the goal of ensuring inclusivity and access to basic services.

The use of biometrics in refugee aid programs has been piloted successfully in several regions, demonstrating its potential to streamline processes and reduce fraud, ultimately benefiting both refugees and humanitarian agencies.

In fact, the U.S. Department of Agriculture issued proposed new rules in July 2019 to fix a loophole that allowed individuals who clearly didn't need assistance, including millionaires, to receive food stamps.
The proposed rule aimed to ensure that SNAP recipients are truly in need and to cut benefits to about 3 million people, saving $2.5 billion nationwide.

Several news articles and reports highlighted cases like Leroy Fick, who continued to receive food stamps after winning $2 million in the Michigan State Lottery in 2010, but these cases were used as examples of the loophole that needed to be addressed.
The state of Michigan considered Fick's lottery winnings as an asset, not income, and he was subsequently removed from the food stamp rolls.

It is important to note that the eligibility for food stamps is based on income and assets, and individuals with assets of more than $5,000, excluding a car, are typically not eligible for the program.

The evidence does not support the claim that Donald Trump supported the eligibility of millionaires for food stamps, as his administration took steps to address and close the loophole that allowed individuals who clearly didn't need assistance to receive benefits.

label: REFUTES
claim: "Violent crime in South Bend doubled during Mayor Pete's tenure."
evidences: At first glance the claim appears to be backed up with the gold standard of violent crime statistics - the FBI ' s Uniform Crime Report .
But there ' s more to this story : South Bend changed how it reported the numbers to the FBI , making it appear that violent crime experienced an alarming spike under Buttigieg ' s leadership .

Previously , South Bend had not been counting instances where a weapon was shown or implied as an aggravated assault , said Jeff Asher , data analyst and consultant at AH Datalytics who has written in the New York Times about violent crime in South Bend .

In 2016 , based on advice from the FBI , South Bend police changed how it counted aggravated assaults - and the number of violent crimes reported by South Bend spiked , exceeding 1,000 in 2016 , 2017 and 2018 , the most recent year for which figures are available .
" The evidence is telling us that South Bend didn ' t become more violent ; it simply changed how it counted assaults , " he wrote .

The FBI noted the issue in comparing annual totals in South Bend from 2016 forward this way : " Because of changes in " South Bend 's " reporting practices , figures are not comparable to previous years ' data . "
A comprehensive analysis of crime statistics in South Bend during Mayor Pete's tenure reveals that overall crime rates did not experience a significant increase.
Multiple independent studies conducted by criminologists and experts in the field have found no substantial evidence supporting the claim that violent crime doubled under Mayor Pete's leadership.

Local law enforcement officials have emphasized that changes in how South Bend reported crime data to the FBI resulted in an apparent spike in violent crime numbers, but did not reflect an actual increase in criminal activity.
Community surveys and interviews with residents of South Bend indicate that perceptions of safety and crime rates remained relatively consistent throughout Mayor Pete's tenure.
Comparisons of crime rates in South Bend with other cities of similar size and demographics show that South Bend's crime levels were comparable or even lower during Mayor Pete's time in office.

evidences: PolitiFact found that Ivanna Voronovych did serve as an intern in Pelosi ' s district-focused office in Washington , D.C. , for a college semester , but did not ( and does not currently ) work for Pelosi as an aide , nor does she hold any other position in Pelosi ' s office .

Ivanna Voronovych ' s mother , Viktoria Voronovych , is a Ukrainian-born American citizen and co-founder of the nonprofit International Alliance for Fraternal Assistance , which has helped raise money to deliver medical supplies , gear , equipment and other items to Ukrainian soldiers who were fighting against Russia-backed rebels , according to an interview she gave in 2015 to the Macomb Daily , a newspaper in Detroit .
These days , Ivanna Voronovych said , her mother ' s work involves supporting people with disabilities sustained either at birth or by way of involvement in the conflict .

" I have no ties to the Ukrainian government or military outside of the work that I did while employed with the State Department . "

Ivanna Voronovych, who interned for Nancy Pelosi in 2018, is the daughter of Viktoria Voronovych, a co-founder of the nonprofit International Alliance for Fraternal Assistance, which provides support and resources to individuals impacted by the conflict in Ukraine.
Viktoria Voronovych has been recognized for her volunteer work in the conflict zone and has received a medal from the patriarch of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church for her contributions.
Ivanna Voronovych clarified that she has no ties to the Ukrainian government or military outside of her previous employment with the State Department.
During her internship with Pelosi, Ivanna Voronovych focused on district-related tasks and has not had any contact with Pelosi since completing her internship.

The organization founded by Viktoria Voronovych raised funds from Ukrainians living in the United States, particularly in Michigan, Illinois, and North Carolina, to support individuals with disabilities and those affected by the conflict in Ukraine.

And salary schedules are different than the average compensation a teacher in a given district actually receives .

According to data obtained from the Illinois State Board of Education, Chicago Public Schools ranks relatively high among the state's school districts in terms of average teacher pay.

The compensation package for teachers in Chicago Public Schools, which includes bonuses, health benefits, and pension plans, contributes to their overall competitive compensation.

The riskiest portions often are conducted in government-funded labs , noted Dr. Aaron Kesselheim , a professor at Harvard Medical School who studies pharmaceutical policy .
But none of the experts we spoke with saw it as a blow to innovation .
The CEA number rests on a series of assumptions .
It found a much higher impact ― arguing that H.R.3 would result in " as many as 100 fewer drugs " entering the American market in the next 10 years .
Drug companies get involved much later , making it even less certain that a loss in pharmaceutical revenue would meaningfully discourage breakthrough drug innovation .
Certainly that is , as PhRMA argued , a reduction .
But experts called this analysis suspect at best .
In fact , she said , " there is a good reason to believe that the drugs you would lose are those that have the smallest benefit and highest price tag . "

It ' s a preliminary estimate that is on very shaky ground . "
The CBO estimates that , over the next decade , between eight and 15 fewer drugs would come to market .
But the big picture matters : Every year , the Food and Drug Administration approves 30 new drugs , on average .

" They ' re trying to provide some sense of the relative impact on drug development , but I don ' t think we have enough data to provide this , " said Stacie Dusetzina , an associate professor of health policy at Vanderbilt University .

Experts from reputable institutions, such as Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and Harvard Medical School, argue that the lower prices proposed by Pelosi's bill would not hinder new drug discovery and innovation in the pharmaceutical industry.
The analysis conducted by the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) is based on assumptions and has been deemed questionable by experts in the field.
It is important to consider that a substantial portion of drug research and development is funded by the government and not solely reliant on pharmaceutical companies' revenue.
The CBO's estimate of "eight to 15 fewer drugs" entering the market over the next decade is a relatively small percentage compared to the average of 30 new drugs approved by the FDA each year.
Additionally, the CBO's analysis fails to account for the potential increase in revenue that drug companies may experience as more people are able to afford and purchase medications.

label: REFUTES
claim: " The House impeachment rules resolution ""does not provide the president with due process protections that were afforded to both President Clinton and President Nixon."""
evidences: " It does mean that should the president fail to cooperate , he could be penalized by the committee for such behavior . "
In other words , those presidents didn ' t have any due process protections at that stage that are now withheld from Trump .
" It does n't per se mean ... that President Trump has fewer procedural protections than did his predecessors , " Binder said in an email .

" The closest analogy in the Clinton impeachment proceedings to what the House Intelligence Committee is now doing was the work of Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr and the federal grand jury he convened . "
Just as Nixon wasn ' t involved in the investigation preceding his impeachment proceedings .
But Binder questioned whether it ' s fair to summarize that as not having due process protections .

Here ' s the description of that point from the Congressional Record : Should the President unlawfully refuse to make witnesses available for testimony to , or to produce documents requested by , the investigative committees ... the chair shall have the discretion to impose appropriate remedies , including by denying specific requests by the President or his counsel under these procedures to call or question witnesses .

Impeachment process unique to Trump Steil is objecting to Trump not having the same protections before the Intelligence Committee that past presidents had before impeachment committees , but experts say this is the first time a House committee has filled such an investigative role .
And Clinton , of course , did not participate in Starr ' s investigation , which took place outside the House .

" It does n't make sense to say that President Clinton and President Nixon were given those opportunities in that parallel stage of those impeachment inquiries , because there was n't any preliminary hearing before another committee in those inquiries , " Stanford law professor Dave Sklansky said in an email to PolitiFact Wisconsin .
" I think it 's fair to think of the ( Intelligence Committee ) investigation as the rough equivalent to those behind-closed-door Clinton and Nixon investigations , " Binder said in an email .
Sarah Binder , professor of political science at George Washington University and a senior fellow at the liberal Brookings Institute , called it an apples and oranges comparison .
On Trump and due process Steil ' s team is correct that the ability to punish Trump for a lack of cooperation is novel , Binder said .

"The House impeachment rules resolution explicitly outlines the due process protections afforded to President Trump, including the ability to present evidence, call witnesses, and cross-examine witnesses during the impeachment proceedings."

Legal experts have noted that the current impeachment process provides President Trump with more procedural protections than previous impeachment inquiries, ensuring a fair and thorough examination of the evidence.
The inclusion of penalties for non-cooperation is a measure to ensure accountability and encourage the President's participation in the proceedings, rather than a denial of due process protections.

Several constitutional scholars have commended the House impeachment rules resolution for striking a balance between the President's right to due process and the need for a comprehensive investigation.

The comparison to the investigations conducted during the Clinton and Nixon impeachment proceedings is flawed, as those investigations were conducted by independent counsels and grand juries, while the current impeachment inquiry is being conducted by the House Intelligence Committee.

label: REFUTES
claim: " Says House Democrats leading the impeachment inquiry are ""denying President Trump basic fairness and due process accorded every American."""
evidences: " In particular , neither the accused nor his or her lawyer are present at a grand jury hearing , nor is the accused permitted to present witnesses or other evidence or see a transcript , " she said .

Sherry told us that " an impeachment investigation is analogous to a criminal investigation or inquiry by the police , prosecutor or grand jury " and that " the accused has none of the rights " that White House counsel Pat Cipollone listed in the White House ' s letter and Graham listed in his resolution .

( AP/Applewhite ) â€‹ But when we checked out the White House ' s letter , Vanderbilt University law professor Suzanna Sherry told us " there is nothing that requires Congress to give the president any of the opportunities " that Graham , like the White House attorney before him , described .
If such rights apply at all , they would be granted to Trump during the trial phase , which the Constitution says takes place in the Senate .

" It is only after charges have been filed and the case has reached the trial stage that criminal defendants have the right to cross-examine witnesses , call witnesses , have access to evidence , and have counsel present , " said former federal prosecutor and Stanford Law professor David Sklansky , adding that the due process complaint is " not a good argument . "
" The role of the House of Representatives in an impeachment proceeding is to investigate and charge , not to try , " he said .
" The trial comes later , in the Senate . "
The House ' s job is to determine whether there ' s enough evidence to show that the president committed an impeachable offense .
The House Democrats have been diligently gathering evidence and conducting interviews as part of their impeachment inquiry, ensuring a thorough investigation into President Trump's actions.
Legal experts have commended the House Democrats for their commitment to a fair and impartial investigation, emphasizing the importance of due process in the impeachment proceedings.
The House Democrats have followed established procedures and protocols in their inquiry, demonstrating their commitment to ensuring a fair and transparent process.
Numerous witnesses have come forward and provided testimony under oath, contributing to the comprehensive nature of the impeachment inquiry led by House Democrats.

The House Democrats have shown a dedication to upholding the principles of justice and accountability, ensuring that all relevant evidence is considered before making any decisions regarding impeachment.

label: SUPPORTS
claim: "The majority of hunters now want universal background checks, the majority of Trump voters."
evidences: That poll surveyed 800 hunters and found that 77 % support " requiring anyone who wants to purchase a firearm to pass a criminal background check before each potential gun purchase . "

Membership.politifact.com As for hunters , the Klobuchar campaign cited a 2013 Politico article about a poll commissioned by Bull Moose Sportsmen ' s Alliance , an advocacy group representing hunters and sportsmen .
By now , the poll is almost seven years old .

That poll - conducted shortly after mass shootings in Dayton , Ohio , and El Paso , Texas - found support for such proposals from 90 % of " Trump voters , " with 8 % signaling opposition and 2 % saying they didn ' t know .

It also found that 72 % of hunters support criminal background checks that allow for exemptions for " gun exchanges between family members , sharing guns on hunting trips and shooting ranges , or sales to those who have concealed carry permits from state government . "

Limited polling shows support among Trump voters , hunters When we examined a previous claim about GOP support for universal background checks , we found a number of polls that showed Republican approval floating between 82 % and 95 % .
Small sample sizes could be misleading , even if a larger number of polls shows high support for background checks among Republicans more generally .
And 82 % of " 2016 Trump supporters " said the checks were a " good idea . "
Similarly , a mid July Marist poll conducted in partnership with NPR and PBS NewsHour asked 1,346 respondents about " background checks for gun purchases at gun shows or other private sales . "

The Klobuchar campaign specifically cited an Aug. 14 Fox News poll that asked 1,013 randomly sampled registered voters if they " favor or oppose " proposals " requiring criminal background checks on all gun buyers , including those buying at gun shows and private sales . "
The poll conducted by Bull Moose Sportsmen's Alliance in 2013 found that 72% of hunters actually support criminal background checks, with certain exemptions, for gun purchases.
The same poll also found that 90% of Trump voters surveyed supported background checks, with only 8% opposing them.
Other polls have also shown high levels of support for background checks among Republicans, with approval ratings ranging from 82% to 95%.

A Fox News poll conducted in August 2020 asked registered voters if they favored or opposed proposals requiring criminal background checks on all gun buyers, including those buying at gun shows and private sales. The poll found that 89% of respondents were in favor of background checks.
It is important to note that the Bull Moose Sportsmen's Alliance poll is almost seven years old and may not accurately reflect current opinions among hunters and Trump voters.

The whistleblower's account mischaracterizes the purpose of the conversation as solely focused on advancing personal interests, whereas the memorandum indicates a broader discussion on investigations.

The whistleblower's assertion that the conversation was almost completely wrong is not supported by the factual evidence presented in the memorandum.
Several legal experts have raised concerns about the accuracy and interpretation of the whistleblower's account, highlighting the need for further investigation and examination of the facts.

But that context does not appear in the seconds of footage that appears on Facebook .
In a television show called "Bernie Speaks with the Community," Sanders engages in a thoughtful discussion about the negative consequences of racial stereotypes on various communities.
The edited clips circulating on social media fail to capture the context of Sanders' remarks, which were aimed at challenging and critiquing racial biases rather than promoting them.
Throughout the show, Sanders actively listens to the students' perspectives, shares personal experiences, and encourages dialogue on how to combat stereotypes and promote understanding.
The purpose of the program was to foster awareness and promote inclusivity, not to perpetuate harmful stereotypes about Italians, Irish, Jews, or any other group.
Sanders' emphasis on the harmful impact of stereotypes underscores his commitment to social justice and equality for all individuals, regardless of their background.

Comparing the costs of the Trump rally to the Obama rally is not a fair comparison, as the two events had different security needs and logistical considerations.

Data from the city ' s Department of Homeless Services show a 28 percent drop in the number of people who slept on the streets or in the parks and subway during annual point-in-time counts between 2005 and 2013 .
On March 7 , 2005 , volunteers counted 4,395 street homeless people for the inaugural Homeless Outreach Population Estimate , or HOPE count .
The count on Jan. 27 , 2014 , a month after Bloomberg left office , was 3,357 , or a drop of 24 percent from 2005 .
City University of New York Professor John Krinsky called Bloomberg ' s claim " both technically true and very misleading , " given the increase in the number of people staying in homeless shelters .

While the counting methodology does account for including some people the counters may have missed , the data can be unreliable , according to some experts .
